author: Stephen L.
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2019
review_content: My wife and I recently had a screened porch converted to a sunroom, and my wife wanted to add some sort of mood/celebratory lighting.  After considering a number of options, we found the Daybetter R5032 at a terrific price, and placed an order for one package.  Once we received the R5032 package, and started considering how we could mount the LED strip(s) we decided we would like to mount the light strips in a trough near the ceiling and use them to provide indirect lighting for the room.  The two 5 meter LED strips would allow us to place lighting along two walls of the sunroom.  Not being able to decide which two walls should carry the lights, it seemed to make more sense to place the lighting all the way around the room so we considered ordering a second R5032.  This would mean that we would have two controllers, and two IR receivers possibly placed in two different locations in the room.  The LED strips come with connectors on both ends making it seem like they could be connected in series, but this is not supported by Daybetter.  The controller has two separate leads each of which connects to one of the 5 meter LED strips.  Connecting both LED strips in series to one of the controller power leads would burn out the controller.  In order to place both IR receivers in the same location, but have one of these controllers control lights that were 5 meters away, we needed extension cables that would allow power from one controller to run to a LED strip 5 meters away.  I contacted Daybetter customer support to ask if they sold such extension cables.  The next day I received an email that said they did not carry any such cables, but they did provide a link to a company that sold such cables through Amazon, and they were willing to help offset the cost of the cables.  Thanks to this quick response, I ordered a second R5032 package from Daybetter, and a set of 4 four-conductor 3 meter extension cables from HUALAND.  Connecting two of the extension cables together gave me enough length to reach an LED strip 5 meters away.  The next issue became how to build a trough in which the LED stips could be mounted.  I found a solution at my local Lowes where I discovered a vinyl door edge that was a bit larger than the 0.5 inch width and height needed to conceal the LED strip.  The size was perfect (UnmountedTrough.jpg), and the price was a tenth of what wood trim would cost to cover the same length.  Since the trough was vinyl, I needed to insure that the LED strips did not generate enough heat to melt them so I laid out the LED strips and turned them on to full brightness to evaluate the amount of heat generated by the circuitry on the strip.  The heat through the resistors on the LED strip was barely detectable.  I painted the door edge trough and installed it at the bottom edge of a 1 x 2 trim piece that already went around the room (Trough+IRsensors.jpg).  I ended up installing the LED strip along the back edge of the trough rather than the bottom of the trough because I did not think the horizontally oriented LED strip would bend nicely around 90 degree corners (LEDinTrough.jpg).  Bending a vertically oriented LED strip around the room's 90 degree corners was no problem.  Once the trough and the LED strips were installed, I then needed to place two power packs and two controllers somewhere hopefully out of sight.  An attic is directly above the sunroom so I decided to drill a hole in one corner of the sunroom ceiling, and route the 4 conductor power cables through the hole into the ceiling where the two power packs and the two controllers would be mounted.  The power pack cords were long enough to allow them to be installed almost anywhere convenient in the attic (PowerPacks+Controllers).  The two controller modules had to be installed right next to the hole in the attic floor so that the IR receiver cables could pass through the hole and be aimed out to the center of the sunroom (Trough+IRsensors.jpg).  One remote control sends a command that is received by both controllers so all light strings react in unison.  The results are highly satisfactory as I hope can be seen from some of the included pictures (LEDsunroom1-7.jpg).  The light strips provide a wide range of colors at about 5 intensity levels, and the adhesive backing made mounting in the trough super simple.  The product works great for us, and the customer support was outstanding.
title: Works as described...Support is terrific!

date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2020
review_content: Your browser does not support HTML5 video.           Very easy to setup and use.Couple tips:1. Make sure the receiver isn't hidden behind anything. The more objects that are between the receiver and the remote will reduce its ability to work.2. The adhesive works great. For best results, make sure the surface you are adhering the light strip to is clean. Even dust can affect how well the strip sticks. We applied it to the top of the crown molding (wiped off first with a dry cloth to remove dust) and it holds well.3. While applying, I found it easier to only peel off around 1-2 feet of the adhesive backing at a time. If you peel off more than that, the uncovered length may fold back and stick to itself.4. For everyone saying the DIY custom lighting option doesn't work - PLEASE watch the video. Yes, there might be instances where a remote doesn't work but we figured it out how to create and set custom colors.- From left to right on the remote, the colors are setup in Red Green Blue (RGB).- Push the DIY button you want to program- Push and hold the DOWN arrow for each color until the lights are completely off. You might have to do it a couple times because it's hard to know if all of one color is off.- When the light strip is completely dark, push the UP arrow for each color to create the DIY color you want. What you're doing is mixing the colors to create a custom color. For example, if you push the RED UP arrow all the way up to its brightest,  and the BLUE UP arrow all the way up to its brightest, it will make a Purple color (Red + Blue = Purple).- When you get the color you want, Push the same DIY button you pushed at the beginning.That's it.

author: dale
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 18, 2020
review_content: My daughter bought something like this from somewhere else and installed them herself.  Her's had connectors in between each strand that daisy chained one to another.  They also had an adhesive that was somewhat forgiving.  Moreover, she got more lights (longer strips) for the same price.So, she figured these were the same and volunteered to install them for her brother.  I thought that was nice of her so I let her go.  That was a mistake on my part.  Unfortunately, these strips have adhesive that is basically permanent.  You don't want to try and take them off if you like your walls.  Moreover, they don't daisy chain.  The power has two connectors on it, and you're supposed to connect the strips directly to the power.My daughter assumed she could daisy chain and completely ignored the additional connector.  She just put them on the walls one right after the other.  I don't know if she read the instructions but I did later and I could see how she would of missed it (thinking they were like hers).  So, we have one strip that lights up, and then a dead strip after that.  She had it working initially by taping the strips together, but that didn't hold.  She left no room for error either, the overlap of the strips was only a couple millimeters.I tried to gently pull off the dead strip, but no matter how careful I was, it took the paint and drywall paper with it.  So, this gets 5 stars for adhesion if that's what you're looking for.  I wasn't really keen on the idea of spackling and repainting the walls so I just left it and sulked.The end of the strip has 4 exposed copper leads.  If you hold them tightly together with the other strip, they do work.  So, I borrowed a couple specific legos from my son's collection.  They are 4x1 and one has a flat spot in the middle. I managed to snap the two strips together with the legos.  Like I said, she only overlapped the strips slightly, so having the lego around both sides of the strips to apply force is tenuous at best, but it is working.It stops working occasionally.  I make sure the legos are firmly pressed together and try to get the connectors closer to each other.  That usually fixes it.  If I get a chance I'll add a picture.So, to sum things up, If you buy these... read the instructions before installing, and/or don't assume they're like the other ones all the kids on Tik Tok are installing themselves ;-)  Be aware the adhesive is strong.  Good luck.
title: Warning: Adhesive is Not Forgiving and Strips Do Not Daisy Chain

author: rebekah
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on July 15, 2020
review_content: Purchased these lights to light up a PC room in my basement.  The set I received had some issues coming on out of the box.  I contacted customer support and they sent out a replacement set right away.  After receiving the new set, they installed in less than 10 minutes.  I attached these to my brick wall in my basement without any issue.  The lights are very bright but are customizable with colors and brightness.  The back drop of these lights are great.  They're really easy on my eyes vs traditional over head lighting working on my PC.  Customer support top notch.  Definitely recommend these lights for the price.
title: Excellent lights for the price.

author: Adrianne Hoefler
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2020
review_content: We ordered these for my daughters room! She LOVES them. Two teenagers put them up. I will say- if you worry about seizures- you may want to avoid these as they have settings that could trigger them.She loves them though and we are very happy with our purchase.
title: Great for bedrooms

author: melany paez
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on February 17, 2020
review_content: the light strip was great when i first got it. the colours worked perfectly fine and the remote did too. the only thing that didn’t work were the diy buttons, which remember any colours you customize. around a month or two part of the strip turned into a completely different colour. when i had it on white two or three of the lights would turn yellow and there is no solution for it. i tried unplugging the strips for a little then plugged them back in, i tried not using them for a night or two, and nothing worked. overall i’m satisfied with my purchase nonetheless since i only use three of the colours on the remote. definitely recommend the strip if you’re just trying to have some cool lighting
title: same strip, different colour.

author: GiGi
date_of_review: Reviewed in the United States on September 19, 2020
review_content: Easy to apply. Simply peel and stick. Adhesive is strong 3M brand. My suggestion would be to measure the length out on the wall first so you are able to line up where the plug should fall, with a wall outlet (and hopefully in an inconspicuous place so the cables aren’t detracting from the beautiful lights. We improvised around the molding and in corners where the plug needed to be reached by trailing the lights vertically in the corner. Look great!! Great product!! Great seller!!
title: Adhesive is strong, great quality, looks terrific, remote is great 👍
